EEXECUTIVE SUMMARY

This Risk Management Plan (RMP) is prepared for barber¿s point facility of BEI Hawaii, formerly know as Brewer Environmental Industries, LLC to address one of the six warehouses statewide which store fertilizer, pesticides, and agricultural and industrial chemicals.  BEI Hawaii developed this site specific Risk Management Plans for BEI Hawaii¿s facility that are regulated under risk management program to comply with Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Accidental Release Prevention requirements: Risk Management Programs under Clean Air Act Section 112(r) and to protect public safety and environment.  The goal of our risk management program is to prevent serious chemical accidents that could cause harm to our employees, the general publics, and the environment and to reduce the potential impact of the accidental release.  Our barber¿s point facility is located at 91-291 Kaomi Loop, Kapolei, on the island of Oahu.

This RMP consists of four chapters.  Chapter 1, Management, introduces the plans and describes the facility operations, management and responsibilities.  Chapter 2, Hazardous Assessment, provides an overview of the chemicals stored in our Barbers Point facility, their hazard release consequences and impact in worst case and alternative scenario, and five-year accident history.  Chapter 3, Prevention Program, provides some safety information, hazard analysis, operation procedures, and prevention procedures.  Chapter 4, Chapter 4, Summary of Emergency Response program.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
BEI Hawaii believes in a clean and safe environment and is dedicated to meeting all applicable environmental standards in the operation of its businesses and services.  BEI Hawaii has established comprehensive policies and procedures for the operations of its facilities.  The policy is a commitment to environmental compliance that assigns the responsibility of implementing the policy to Chief Executive Officer o

f the company, or designated individual or individuals to ensure compliance.   The purpose of the policy is to provide employees with a safe and healthy working environment, and to protect the environmental from pollutions.

Preservation of the environment is a commitment that must be shared by all employees.  Employees shall promptly report suspected violations of environmental laws, regulations or permits to their supervisor who shall take immediate action to verify the report and, If confirmed, stop the violation and take remedial or other appropriate action.   The incident shall be promptly reported to BEI Hawaii¿s Regulatory Compliance manager, who will assist in making any necessary reports to regulatory agencies.

Overall approach to chemical safety begins with the premise that safety is everyone¿s responsibility and working safely is a condition of employment. Workplace hazards are minimized through preventive measures such as facility and equipment design, purchase of less hazardous products and development of standard operating procedures. Control measures include facility inspections to discover potential problems, employee reports of hazardous conditions, training and a safety award program.   




Stationary Source and Regulated Substance 

The facility stores pesticides, fertilizers (bulk and bagged) and industrial chemicals.  The facility has   following RMP regulated substance: chlorine, anhydrous sulfur dioxide h., and anhydrous ammonia.  The products are mainly warehoused and distributed from the facility mainly on Oahu as well as throughout the State of Hawaii.

The site is leasehold with Campbell Estates being the leaseholder and consists of approximately 6.2 acres.   The site is bounded on the north by Chevron Hawaii Refinery, undeveloped parcels to the south and east and the Pacific Ocean and shoreline to the west.

Release Scenarios
Two release scenarios (worst case scenario and alternative scenario) have been assessed for chlorine, anhydrous

Sulfur Dioxide and Anhydrous ammonia.
a) Worst Case scenario release
The release scenario is the total release of the largest quantity of the regulated chemical from a one-ton cylinder and a 15-ton tanker.  There is no passive mitigation and the release occurs under the worst weather conditions.

	b) Alternative Scenario release

The alternative scenario is most likely to occur than the worst case, and there is an active mitigation measure that can limit the amount of release.   

In both cases the OCA Guidance was used to determine the distance to the toxic endpoint.

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Steps
The facility complies with the OSHA Process Safety Management rule.   A process safety management plan was written for the facility that includes all of the required elements.   Since the process is storage only, the practices important to the prevention program are the proper storage and handling of the chlorine and anhydrous sulfur dioxide cylinders.  Dry, isolated and fireproof storage spaces are provided where the temperature of the vicinity of the cylinders never reaches 140 degrees Fahrenheit.  Proper loading and unloading of cylinders from trucks are very important to prevent cylinders from falling and cause possible damage to the valve area.  Training and careful work practices are the key to preventing accidental damage to the cylinders.

Five-Year Accident History
The facility has not experienced any accidents involved to RMP regulated substance during the past five years.  This is understandable because the process is mainly storage only with minimal using of the chlorine on site.  This site had a sulfuric acid spill on Nov. 25 1999 but it is not RMP regulated substance.


Emergency Response Program
The BEI HAWAII ¿ Barber¿s Point facility is classified as a non-responding facility.  As such, BEI HAWAII has developed an Emergency Action Plan to ensure employee/community safety, rather than a full-fledged emergency response wi

th an in-house response team.  The BEI HAWAII - Barber¿s Point Facility has developed its own procedures as outlined in the BEI HAWAII Safety and Health Program incorporating information from Chlorine Institute Pamphlet 64, Emergency Response Plans for Chlorine Facilities and others.  BEI HAWAII has coordinated response to incidents with the Honolulu Fire Department Hazmat Team located in Oahu.  Operators are capable, however, of responding to incidental releases such as routine tightening of a valve, for example. 

BEI HAWAII ¿ Barber¿s Point facility personnel will only perform defensive mitigation measures (i.e., secure areas, initiate water spray, etc.,) to limit the release until a response team arrives to establish the incident command.  We have discussed this program with the Local Emergency Planning Committee and the Honolulu Fire Department.  In addition, BEI HAWAII has arranged with local response contractors to deal with potential releases at the facility.  

Planned change to improve safety
There is no plan to change the present operation for chlorine, sulfur dioxide, and anhydrous ammonia primarily because the process is storage BEI Hawaii eliminated several other chemicals and reduced chemical inventory amount.  Chlorine use especially by swimming pools and sewage treatment plants is being eliminated and substituted with bleach or hypochlorite in powdered or tablet form depending on the size of the facility.  This will enable BEI Hawaii to reduce the chlorine inventory.
